content.question: The figure shows some of the energy levels for a hypothetical atom. A photon of wavelength <math alttext="487 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>487</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has an energy of <math alttext="2.55 electron-volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.55</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>eV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following correctly indicates whether the absorption spectrum of a collection of these atoms will have a dark line at <math alttext="487 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>487</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and describes a feature of the model that indicates this? (The absorption spectrum does not include any process that ionizes the atom.)

choices.label: Yes. The atom has energy levels that have magnitudes less than <math alttext="2.55 electron-volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.55</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>eV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Yes. The atom has an energy level that is exactly the same energy as a <math alttext="487 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>487</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> photon.

No. The atom does not have a transition between levels with an energy difference equal to the energy of a <math alttext="487 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>487</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> photon.

No. The atom has only one level that is an integer multiple of <math alttext="2.55 electron-volts" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.55</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>eV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.
